Manufacturers made products that had perhaps a few dozen competitors, at most, somwhere within the US.Things changed between that time period and around 2010. We refer to it as globalization and advanced technologies but it also included advances in communications, automation, transportation and management.By 2010, these advances had added about 2.3 billion people to the total worker job market by making it possible to efficiently use labor in China and India and Korea and other nations. These workers were in direct competition with American workers for a lot of jobs but these workers had very different expectations of wages and working conditions. They were quite willing to worl for lower wages and in less than ideal working environments.By 2010, these advances had also added hundreds of thousands of business competitors to the karket place. American businesses were now competition against businesses that paid much lower wages and fewer benefits and had much lower overhead costs. This was true even among other American businesses that had taken advantage of foreign labor, automation and robotics.The result is that the consumer has driven businesses to seek the lowest possible labor and overhead costs so that they can compete in price with the entire global market. The workers have to work at lower wages and take on more hours or work two jobs to make the same amount of income.We now live in a global market in which every business competes against other businesses from all over the world and every worker competes for jobs with workers from all over the world.The consumer is buying the lowest cost products from all over the world which means that consumers in America can strongly influence a business or labor market in China or India.All this happened in about a 20 to 30 year period and it is still going on.In the next 20–30 years, even the low cost human labor in India and China and other countries will be replaced by automation and robotics that will work 24x7 at a fraction the the effective labor wages.
